instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.BLK_EN: What is BLK_EN? This is a typo of BKL_EN When you see BLK_EN, assume they meant to type BKL_EN.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Backlight
threads.message:
Hello,
this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B has no Backlight. No waterdamage or other visible damage on the board. I measured around and <SIGNAL>BLK_EN</SIGNAL> is only 3.0V. I chekhed the voltage divider (both resistors are fine) and came to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. It is only 12.22V. I can clearly see it working on the screen and i can use it with an external monitor. Everything else works fine. I tried a different screen and still no light. I already exchanged <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> to be sure but still the same measurements. Can this be a SMC problem if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is stuck at 12.22V even if everything else works?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Backlight
threads.message:
3V on enable is fine. 12.3V on PPBUS would at least indicate a problem with SMBUS to battery but should not affect backlight. 
Did you do a PRAM reset? <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Backlight
threads.message: If i unplug the battery <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> comes back up to 12.6V. It runs from Battery and charges it. When booted up into guest user <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> is 0V. <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> is <50ohm and diode mode reading of <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> is 0.43V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Backlight
threads.message: I cant believe it. The PRAM reset did the trick. I thought i already tried that... Maybe the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> was bad too.... Any idea what could cause this? Some wrong settings maybe?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no Backlight
threads.message: Dunno, sometimes you need to do PRAM reset and then totally power off and on again.
